slides.title: What is Money?
slides.description: An overview of the fundamental concept of money.
content: Money is a medium of exchange, a unit of account, and a store of value.
Throughout history, money has taken different forms, including commodities, coins, and paper.

slides.title: Commodity Money
slides.description: The first form of money was based on valuable goods.
content: People used valuable commodities like gold, silver, and salt as money.
The problem was that these items were not always easy to transport or divide.

slides.title: Rise of Coins
slides.description: The first standardized coins were created for easier trade.
content: Around 600 BC, the Lydians created the first metal coins.
Coins made transactions easier because they had a fixed value.

slides.title: The Birth of Paper Money
slides.description: How paper money replaced metal coins as the dominant form of currency.
content: In the 11th century, China introduced the first government-backed paper money.
Unlike coins, banknotes were easier to transport and store.

slides.title: Digital Money
slides.description: The rise of digital transactions and cryptocurrencies.
content: Credit cards and online banking revolutionized payments in the 20th century.
Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies introduced a decentralized form of digital money.

terms.commodity money: Money whose value comes from the commodity it is made of, such as gold, silver, or salt.
terms.mintage: The process of producing coins and assigning them a nominal value.
terms.banknote: A paper note issued by a bank that represents a certain amount of money.
terms.inflation: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services rises, eroding purchasing power.
terms.digital money: Currency that exists only in digital form, such as cryptocurrencies or bank account balances.
